title: Eduardo Almeida
text:
Eduardo Filipe Arroja Almeida (born 22 March 1978), commonly known as Eduardo Almeida, is a Portuguese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager for <a href="Liga%201%20%28Indonesia%29">Liga 1</a> club <a href="Arema%20F.C.">Arema</a>.
Managerial career.
Eduardo holds the <a href="UEFA%20Pro%20Licence">UEFA Pro Licence</a>, the highest football coaching qualification. He received the UEFA Pro Licence in 2011 from the <a href="Portuguese%20Football%20Federation">Portuguese Football Federation</a>. He also holds a degree in Sports and Physical Education from the <a href="Universidade%20Lus%C3%B3fona">Universidade Lusófona</a>.
Portugal.
He began his managerial career in 2001 as the assistant manager of the U-16 team of Portuguese club <a href="S.L.%20Benfica">S.L. Benfica</a>. He worked as an assistant to former Portuguese international, <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Lu%C3%ADs%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201958%29">José Luís</a>. Later in 2003 he was appointed as the head coach of the U-17 team of Benfica. In a four-year long spell, he worked at the grassroots level of the club and helped in the development of young footballers.
In 2004, he was appointed as the head coach of the U-19 team of <a href="Almeirim">Almeirim</a>-based side, União Futebol Clube de Almeirim on a one-year contract.
He then moved to <a href="Agualva-Cac%C3%A9m">Agualva-Cacém</a> in 2005 where he signed a two-year contract to be appointed as the assistant manager of <a href="Terceira%20Divis%C3%A3o">Terceira Divisão</a> side, Atlético Clube do Cacém where he worked as an assistant to Portuguese football manager <a href="Pedro%20Valido">Pedro Valido</a>.
Hong Kong.
He first moved out of <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a> in 2007 to <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> where he was appointed as the manager of <a href="Hong%20Kong%20First%20Division%20League">Hong Kong First Division League</a> side, <a href="South%20China%20AA">South China AA</a>. In his short spell in Hong Kong, he helped his side win the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Hong%20Kong%20First%20Division%20League">2007–08 Hong Kong First Division League</a> and the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Hong%20Kong%20League%20Cup">2007–08 Hong Kong League Cup</a>.
Back to Portugal.
He moved back to Portugal in 2008 and was appointed as the manager of his former club, Atlético Cacém.
Tanzania.
He again moved out of Portugal in 2009 to <a href="Tanzania">Tanzania</a> where he was appointed as the manager of <a href="Tanzanian%20Premier%20League">Tanzanian Premier League</a> side, <a href="African%20Lyon%20F.C.">African Lyon F.C.</a> He helped the <a href="Dar%20es%20Salaam">Dar es Salaam</a>-based side secure the 5th position in the 2009–10 season of the Tanzanian Premier League.
Back to Portugal.
After a short spell in Tanzania, he moved back to Portugal in 2010 where he was appointed as the assistant manager of <a href="Portuguese%20Second%20Division">Portuguese Second Division</a> side, <a href="Real%20S.C.">Real S.C.</a> where he worked as an assistant to Portuguese football manager <a href="Jorge%20Amaral%20Rodrigues">Jorge Amaral Rodrigues</a>.
He then moved to <a href="Figueira%20da%20Foz">Figueira da Foz</a> in 2011 where he was appointed as the assistant manager of <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Naval%201%C2%BA%20de%20Maio">Associação Naval 1º de Maio</a> on a one-year contract. He worked as an assistant to former <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>ian international, <a href="Carlos%20Mozer">Carlos Mozer</a>.
In 2012, he moved to <a href="Reguengos%20de%20Monsaraz">Reguengos de Monsaraz</a> where he was appointed as the manager of <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20S.C.">Atlético S.C.</a> on a one-year contract.
Malaysia.
After a three year long spell in Portugal, he moved out to <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> where he signed a one-year contract to be appointed as the manager of <a href="Malaysia%20Super%20League">Malaysia Super League</a> side, <a href="T%E2%80%93Team%20F.C.">T–Team F.C.</a> He was appointed as a replacement for former <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United F.C.</a> player, <a href="Peter%20Butler%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201966%29">Peter Butler</a> and was given the responsibility of avoiding relegation to the <a href="Malaysia%20Premier%20League">Malaysia Premier League</a>.
Hungary.
In December 2014, he moved out to <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a> where on 17 December, he was appointed as the manager of <a href="Koz%C3%A1rmisleny">Kozármisleny</a>-based <a href="Nemzeti%20Bajnoks%C3%A1g%20II">Nemzeti Bajnokság II</a> side, <a href="Koz%C3%A1rmisleny%20SE">Kozármisleny SE</a> on a short-term contract. He helped his side secure 13 points in 14 matches in a short-spell at the club, emerging victorious against <a href="Szolnoki%20M%C3%81V%20FC">Szolnoki MÁV FC</a>, <a href="V%C3%A1rda%20SE">Várda SE</a> and Hungarian club <a href="B%C3%A9k%C3%A9scsaba%201912%20El%C5%91re">Békéscsaba 1912 Előre</a>.
Back to Tanzania.
He moved back to Tanzania and to his former club African Lyon in 2014.
Laos.
In December 2014, he made a far away move to <a href="Laos">Laos</a> where he was appointed as the manager of <a href="Lao%20Premier%20League">Lao Premier League</a> side, <a href="Lanexang%20United%20F.C.">Lanexang United F.C.</a> In his short spell at the <a href="Vientiane">Vientiane</a>-based side, he helped them secure the 2nd position in the <a href="2015%20Lao%20Premier%20League">2015 Lao Premier League</a>.
Back to Portugal.
He moved back to Portugal in December 2015 and was appointed as the manager of <a href="Campeonato%20de%20Portugal%20%28league%29">Campeonato de Portugal</a> side, <a href="C.D.%20Pinhalnovense">C.D. Pinhalnovense</a> on a one-year contract. He helped his side avoid relegation to <a href="Portuguese%20District%20Championships">Portuguese District Championships</a> securing major wins against SR Almancilense and <a href="F.C.%20Barreirense">F.C. Barreirense</a>. He parted company with the <a href="Pinhal%20Novo">Pinhal Novo</a>-based side without any loss and 2 wins in the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Campeonato%20de%20Portugal">2016–17 Campeonato de Portugal</a>.
He moved to <a href="Angra%20do%20Hero%C3%ADsmo">Angra do Heroísmo</a> in October 2016 where on 31 October he was appointed as the manager of another Campeonato de Portugal side, <a href="S.C.%20Angrense">S.C. Angrense</a>.
Back To Malaysia.
June 2017 marks his return to Malaysia when he was appointed as the new head coach of <a href="Melaka%20United">Melaka United</a>. Safe the team from relegation and renew contract, However, in May 2018 finish part away with club with mutual agreement.
Go to Thailand.
In December 2018 sign a 2 years contract with Ubon United but left the team in May 2019 because team have financial problems.
Go to Indonesia.
On september 2019 sign with Semen Padang F.C. in Superleague Indonesia. 
2021 sign with Arema FC also in Indonesia Superleague.
Honours.
Individual
